---
title: "Minimal Template"
description: "The smallest runnable Mizu project template"
---

# Minimal Template

The `minimal` template creates the smallest possible runnable Mizu project. Perfect for learning, quick prototypes, or starting with a clean slate.

## Create Project

```bash
mizu new myapp --template minimal
cd myapp
go mod tidy
mizu dev
```

## Generated Structure

```
myapp/
├── .gitignore
├── README.md
├── go.mod
└── main.go
```

**Only 4 files!** Everything you need to start building.

## Generated Files

### `main.go`

The entry point with a single route:

```go
package main

import (
    "log"

    "github.com/go-mizu/mizu"
)

func main() {
    app := mizu.New()

    app.Get("/", func(c *mizu.Ctx) error {
        return c.Text(200, "Hello from myapp\n")
    })

    log.Println("listening on :8080")
    if err := app.Listen(":8080"); err != nil {
        log.Fatal(err)
    }
}
```

### `go.mod`

Module configuration:

```go
module example.com/myapp

go 1.25

require github.com/go-mizu/mizu v0.0.0
```

### `.gitignore`

Standard Go ignores for binaries, test artifacts, and IDE files.

### `README.md`

Basic documentation with setup and running instructions.

## Quick Start

```bash
# Create the project
mizu new myapp --template minimal

# Enter directory
cd myapp

# Install dependencies
go mod tidy

# Run in development mode
mizu dev
```

Test your application:

```bash
curl http://localhost:8080/
# Hello from myapp
```

## Customization

### Custom Module Path

```bash
mizu new myapp --template minimal --module github.com/myorg/myapp
```

### Custom Project Name

The project name appears in the response:

```bash
mizu new myapp --template minimal --name "My Awesome App"
```

## Extending the Minimal Template

### Add More Routes

```go
func main() {
    app := mizu.New()

    // Existing route
    app.Get("/", func(c *mizu.Ctx) error {
        return c.Text(200, "Hello from myapp\n")
    })

    // Add JSON endpoint
    app.Get("/api/status", func(c *mizu.Ctx) error {
        return c.JSON(200, map[string]any{
            "status": "ok",
            "name":   "myapp",
        })
    })

    // Add POST endpoint
    app.Post("/api/echo", func(c *mizu.Ctx) error {
        body := c.BodyString()
        return c.Text(200, body)
    })

    log.Println("listening on :8080")
    if err := app.Listen(":8080"); err != nil {
        log.Fatal(err)
    }
}
```

### Add Middleware

```go
func main() {
    app := mizu.New()

    // Add logging middleware
    app.Use(func(c *mizu.Ctx) error {
        log.Printf("%s %s", c.Method(), c.Path())
        return c.Next()
    })

    app.Get("/", func(c *mizu.Ctx) error {
        return c.Text(200, "Hello from myapp\n")
    })

    log.Println("listening on :8080")
    if err := app.Listen(":8080"); err != nil {
        log.Fatal(err)
    }
}
```

### Add Configuration

```go
package main

import (
    "log"
    "os"

    "github.com/go-mizu/mizu"
)

func main() {
    // Simple config from environment
    addr := os.Getenv("ADDR")
    if addr == "" {
        addr = ":8080"
    }

    app := mizu.New()

    app.Get("/", func(c *mizu.Ctx) error {
        return c.Text(200, "Hello from myapp\n")
    })

    log.Printf("listening on %s", addr)
    if err := app.Listen(addr); err != nil {
        log.Fatal(err)
    }
}
```

## When to Use

<Check>
**Use the minimal template when:**
- Learning Mizu fundamentals
- Building a quick prototype
- Creating a single-file utility
- You want full control over project structure
- Starting from scratch with custom architecture
</Check>

<Warning>
**Consider the API template instead when:**
- Building a production service
- Working with a team
- Need graceful shutdown
- Want feature-based organization
- Building a REST API with multiple resources
</Warning>

## Comparison with API Template

| Feature | Minimal | API |
|---------|---------|-----|
| Files | 4 | 15+ |
| Graceful shutdown | No | Yes |
| Configuration | No | Yes |
| Feature separation | No | Yes |
| Health endpoint | No | Yes |
| Signal handling | No | Yes |
